What do you guys think about the design to show next unread topic / pm above compose box. Screenshot-2022-02-02-173710.png Screenshot-2022-02-02-174325.png Screenshot-2022-02-02-174339.png

Any design ideas are welcome!
The number of unread topic / pm attract more attention if we include them.

I feel like these belong just under the search bar, since they are all navigation related. I like showing the unread counts. I would argue that we don't really need "Recent topics" anywhere other than the top left corner, and if people are having trouble finding it there, then we should do a minor tweak such as putting it above "All messages". I we were to omit "Recent topics" from your design (whether or not you agree it should be just below the search bar) then we could hide the line when you don't have unread messages.
Of your three screenshots I like the last one the best.

I don't understand the improvement. There are already ways to do this thing: hot keys, left panel, All messages stream to scroll through things.
Buttons at the bottom look like unnecessary objects

can't speak to the whole feature, but lately I've been wanting a "go to next unread message" button in interleaved views. (I tend to have the same zulips open in tabs on multiple laptops.) So something along the lines of this feature seems quite good.
My interpretation of the rationale for this proposed change is that the n key is a very useful feature that mouse-centric users should be able to discover and/or use without memorizing the hotkey.
<looks up n key> hm, yes, discovery for that would be nice, but not quite what I'm looking for. carry on :)
If we go with this change, we should make it so that it teaches folks the hotkeys.
I challenge you guys to fit any kind of buttons in a single bottom bar. That is a good visual and UX limit
If the action you are talking is a very frequent or you know that users really want it… sure
But if its just some thing that people might do after they scrolled to the bottom of the topic - use that under the topic space to suggest all kind of things to so next
I think almost any place would be better for these proposed buttons, including somewhere in the left sidebar. I don’t think they even need to always show on the main page.
Yes, the idea of not “always show them” is a general suggestion which I support

For reference, this is the original issue: #18728.

The n ("Next unread topic") and p ("Next unread private message") keyboard shortcuts are a great way to read through one's Zulip messages. At present, we don't have buttons that correspond to these shortcuts. Adding these buttons would make this workflow more accessible to mouse users, and more discoverable.

We should therefore add the following buttons:

  1. "Next unread topic (n)" button in the blank space at the bottom of a topic narrow. No button if there are no unread topics.
  2. "Next unread PM thread (p) button in the blank space at the bottom of a PM conversation narrow. No button if there are no unread PM threads.

We will need to experiment with the design and exact placement of these buttons.

CZO discussion
So the original proposal was to just have one button, and have it be context-dependent based on whether you're in a topic or a PM thread.

I feel pretty strongly that in order to be useful as a way to go through topics quickly, as an alternative for mouse users to using n, one should generally be able to click the button without moving the mouse much or even at all. So, e.g. with an external mouse, you can use the scroll wheel to get to the bottom of a topic, and then click without moving the mouse.

Somewhere towards the bottom of the message feed seems to me like a natural place to keep one's cursor (at least, that's what I do), and a natural place to find the "next" button. So that's where I was imagining it would go.

But maybe we could train users to keep their mouse in one of the alternative locations you guys were suggesting?

Aman Agrawal (amanagr) said:

The number of unread topic / pm attract more attention if we include them.

I guess what's challenging about the counts for me, is that I'm not sure looking at that whether it's the number of topics with any unreads in them, or the total number of unread messages.

Generally mouse users switch narrows from the left sidebar, correct? Even in my loquacious moments I would say that I only reply to about 30% of topics, and I suspect that percentage is even lower for most folks.
I use n a lot, and the left sidebar when trying to decide what stream to go to next. Would be curious to hear from others. :)
(So I am somewhat skeptical to put navigation buttons near the compose box.)

I don’t think near a compose box is a problem and I agree with Alia to put them right under the end of the topic/series if messages where there is natural white space. Right I think there is a link in some cases on a separator line - that kind of thing
Is the small tweak to Aman’s example to put the buttons closer to the bottom message?
(Just asking for clarification.)
i think that those buttons should be scrolled as content and not being present at times
Should we try something more similar to the date line design we plan to use for advertising recent topics to logged out users? #20133
sticked above compose

Another direction that we can think about would be for "next unread topic" to be a button that appears in the left sidebar in the top area.

I agree this one is probably one of the best options and worth trying.

A few notes on details we will need to think about/resolve:

  • We have other things we put at the end of the message feed, such as a loading indicator in rare cases if you started in a search high up and went to the bottom, and a "Subscribe" button if you're looking at a stream you're not subscribed to. How should this relate to those? My initial answer is this should always be after these things (including bit of vertical buffer we leave for the loading indicator so that it can disappear without anything changing position).
  • How do we handle the "Next unread topic" vs. "Next unread PM" issue -- e.g. should what we offer depend on whether you're currently looking at a topic or a PM conversation? (Or do we show both, which would make the element a lot bigger?)
  • How do we handle the interactions if you have no unreads of the relevant type? Does it just result in a thing you can click that doesn't do anything, or that pops a small "You've read everything" tooltip, or something else?
  • There's a potential interaction with this specific position that it will be an element that moves down every time a new message arrives, and that could be annoying/distracting. I don't think we can easily evaluate whether that'll be a real problem until we try it.
Updated #20244

Nice! After playing around with it, my main concern is that I think the fact that the placement of the button depends on how many messages you have on screen makes it a lot harder to use. You might have to move the mouse every time you switch topics.

I think we want a placement that doesn't move as you switch topics. You could then leave the cursor in one spot as you scroll with the mouse wheel, or just click without scrolling when all unreads fit on the screen.
Maybe it could be in a fixed location just above the compose box? It's fine if it moves (or even disappears?) if the compose box is open.
If there are no issues then we should test deploy it since others wanted to try it out. We can iterate on having it above the compose box after a few days.
Sure, since it sounds like it won't be super-easy to address my comment, we can try it out here to give more folks a feel for it.
I test-deployed this here earlier today!

A few observations:

  • The notice disappears when you start composing a message -- it's not clear to me if this is intentional, but it feels like a strange interaction.
  • When using the button repeatedly, the current placement in the message feed is annoying, because it moves to a different vertical position in each thread, so it's hard to jump to a new topic multiple times. This may be impossible to solve... One kinda also wants the position of the button to be one where mousewheel scrolling works in the message feed.
  • It does feel nice to have a thing one can click to go to the next unread topic.

I'm finding it somewhat invasive so far, I think in part because it's pretty close to the last message. We may be able to address this when we tackle the other placement issue, but we might also want the UI to be smaller (e.g. shorter text or a button with some symbol) for an element one is going to see so often.
Yeah, I think part of the issue is the full-width line (which looks like a date change separator) is distracting. But another part of it is just having it be so close to the last message.

This was my proposal above:

Maybe it could be in a fixed location just above the compose box? It's fine if it moves (or even disappears?) if the compose box is open.
Yeah, I think it's worth trying that -- the other direction one could try is having it be a cousin to the "Jump to bottom" button.

It's hard to find the existence of the "next unread topic" with its current. It only shows up when I am in a topic narrow and when I have reached the last message of that narrow. This is different from just pressing n, where I can do it from stream/topic narrow, and even without having to reach the end of the thread. I think it should be a button in the bottom bar.
OK, nvm, most people who properly use Zulip spend more time in topic narrow anyway

Rein Zustand said:

OK, nvm, most people who properly use Zulip spend more time in topic narrow anyway

I think it is important we teach people how to properly use Zulip too.

Yeah, I think it's worth trying that -- the other direction one could try is having it be a cousin to the "Jump to bottom" button.

That looks worth trying too.

Guys... Next unread topic in the middle of the screen is too visible.
I suggest to volume down it visually (making it grey) and move to the right side.

I've dropped this experiment for now -- I think we've gotten some useful information on potential bugs, and maybe some experience that will help us think through where it should go (which I think is quite thorny, as discussed above).

Feedback would be appreciated, both ideas for where we should put it, as well as whether you found yourself clicking it during the day or so that it was live (aka whether you found it useful).
random feedback to this idea: I usually find myself wanting a "next unread message" button/hotkey (perhaps better phrased as "last read message") instead of a "next unread topic."
I'm not sure I understand -- are you talking about a proposed different phrasing, or different behavior?
behavior, I think
thus it being pretty random, as feedback goes

I think the detail of whether we take you to the next unread or the message before would be an independent thing to work on (#10886), this discussion is about how to do a button that is equivalent to the n hotkey.

oh, was not aware there was a separate issue. carry on, then.
(my use case is that I spend most of my time interleaved, with the same zulips open on different machines, and want to jump to the same "place" I've been on on another machine. as it turns out, just reloading the browser tab technically achieves this, though slowly and a bit painfully.)

Yeah, I think it's worth trying that -- the other direction one could try is having it be a cousin to the "Jump to bottom" button.

We could convert scroll to bottom button to next unread at the end of narrows.
An updated version of this was [test-deployed[(https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/415-chat.2Ezulip.2Eorg/topic/experiments/near/1414753) just now.

I think the premise of showing this is great!

Thoughts:

  • bright blue seems very distinctive; do we have another example of a 'workflow' action color to match it with? Or maybe just tone it down?
  • do we show a 'hotkey' anywhere else in the webapp UI, without hover? (we do in ZT, but I've not seen in it in the web app)
  • should it take a similar style to the 'buttons' in the side panels, eg. highlighting differently on hover? (and showing the hotkey?)

AFAIK we don't have other hotkeys displayed in the UI without hover, except for the compose box corner:

image.png

My experience so far is that I have been finding this specific implementation fairly distracting. I think there's a few things going on, though I'm not really sure which are important:

  • It disappears when one opens the compose box, which creates a flash that draws my eyes. I understand why we want to do that, I think (the keyboard shortcut won't work inside the compose box?) but I'm not sure that's the right tradeoff.
  • The full-width horizontal line makes it a fairly large element.
  • The colors are not very consistent with what we use elsewhere.

I haven't used it enough to consider the compose box issue (which I read about).

The ctrl+enter point is interesting, but it's certainly not styled like this.

I don't object to the element size, though it's possibly a little far down from the last message. I think it looks good as a 'beyond last message' indicator.
My experience is similar to Tim's here. Adding it to the recipient bar could be a better direction to keep the UI clean. Any text sitting in the white empty space would be distracting I guess.

I agree with the feedback to above that we need to make it more subtle... I'm also still very interested in trying some variant where the button stays in a fixed location on the screen (even if we only show it when the topic is scrolled all the way down), so that one can click on it repeatedly without having to move the mouse around.
Any ideas on where we'd put such a button? I suppose one idea is we could put it in some of the dead space in the middle of the recipient bar (at least on desktop widths).

In other words, in the middle of the grey region here:

image.png
The other natural option is putting it under "Drafts" in the left sidebar.
https://chat.zulip.org/#narrow/stream/101-design/topic/Next.20unread.20.2320244/near/1322429 There are some screenshots above to make better decision.

So currently this hangs off the last message, and the concern is that the button moves for mouse users?

I see Aman Agrawal (amanagr) had a design with it at the bottom, which I assume had it 'hanging above' the bar there instead and being uncovered when messages scroll up? That seems sort of OK, but sort of breaks the concept I feel of the 'continuing down beyond this topic' that the indicator represents. I'm also not sure how the 'uncovering' would work.

One thought was to limit the whitespace at the bottom of scrolling messages, but of course that fails with the 1-message case where we naturally pin the message to the top - unless we really change the design! So otherwise if we really want the 'fixed position for clicking' then I suppose it has to be stuck to the bottom - it doesn't sound as good, but if it works better for clicking and that's a priority then maybe try that.

Having a 'relative to current narrow' button in the side panel seems like it would be out of place and confusing compared to the absolute nature of the others? Having it in the recipient bar seems like it would look out of place, unless it was somehow outside the message list margins - which I think is why the place it currently is works so well.
@Alya Abbott lets discuss it on a meeting please. The idea is to stick this button to the compose box but in a way that you don't think so...
